rComments: Kenichi is approachable and tries to make lectures engaging by using video clips and even showing his kids, who are really cute, in examples. For the essays, just go to your TA and be very specific in your analysis. Show up to lectures and work on your essays with your TA and you'll be fine!

Don't bother buying the textbook for this course. Ariga's lectures are incredibly long and dry but the concepts are relatively simple to understand. Free marks just by participating in class using an iClicker and through attending tutorials.

I was so scared to take this class, actually very interesting and manageable. The concepts are straight forward and if you keep up throughout the semester you will do fine. Prof is not interesting, but go to lecture! Make sure you talk to your TA's, essay grades matter a lot. Class average was in the C range.

Ariga may not be the most engaging lecturer, but he is extremely thorough. His lectures are only a little dry because he really takes his time to explain what hes talking about (again, hes thorough). The upside is that his grading criteria is extremely clear. Follow his instructions and youre guranteed an easy A. Hes also very accessible.

Professor Ariga gives perhaps the most clear rubrics and expectations of any professor I have had. However, if you do not have a clear grasp on quantitative politics, you may struggle in his class. He is soft-spoken in lecture and approachable outside of class, and without his guidance, the course would have been more difficult.
teacherRatingTags: ['Gives good feedback', 'Accessible outside class', 'Clear grading criteria']

rComments: He was a great prof! I was really worried about this class, but he made the content really straightforward and easy to understand! His lectures were also fun since we got to use the iClickers. Definitely take his class.
Nice professor. Has great slides which are packed with helpful information for the exams. The TAs seemed to grade the essays pretty harshly. Overall a good choice.
teacherRatingTags: ['Clear grading criteria', "Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Tough grader']

rComments: His class has to be one of the most well-organized at this school. He + his TAs are helpful and know the material. Only critique is that he goes super quick during lectures, so it's hard to keep up with what he's saying, but you should be alright if you review his slides. He basically gives you 15% of your grade for free, which is much appreciated.
Really good professor, the lectures are engaging and clear, his slides are also very clear and to the point. The essays reflect the classwork and participation marks are easy to obtain!
Professor Ariga is all around nice and his lectures are interesting. I've actually used the content from this course in my everyday life. Who would have guess school actually teaches you things!
Professor Ariga is a real gem. He is caring and a true intellectual. The course is not too bad, you need show up though cause of the iclicker! Cool videos are shown in class too.

Overall nice prof: he provides tons of extra help outside of lectures so if you dedicate your time to the material you'll get an 80+. Some words of warning: his lectures, and the material, are pretty boring, so be prepared to use the textbook and extra help. Also, he has a strong accent but I was still able to understand him if I wasn't distracted.
Can't understand anything he says. The lectures are so redundant. Terrible class.

Professor Ariga is a really good professor and I feel like he hasn't been given enough credits. His slides are informative and he always explains them carefully during lectures. He is a very well-rounded professor.

Love him. I can't say enough good things about how much of a blessing he is, since I've taken some truly horribly organized courses. Everything is so meticulous, clear, organized, well-planned, and thoughtful. Lecture slides are crystal clear. A large part of the grade is easy marks. His lectures are easy to understand, accent considered.

I really like this prof, as he aligns the readings, slides and speaking aspects all into one every week, which is a nice change for U of T. If you put some effort into listening, his accent is pretty good for ESL prof and is the best to teach quantitative reasoning, he explains the concept quite thoroughly.

Prof. Ariga's lectures are very well organized, and backed by the best slide presentations I've ever seen in a class.  The slides are a perfect takeaway from each lecture, both for the purpose of studying for the exam and as a reference for future comprehension.  He is very happy to review anything that students find unclear.

I liked this class, the lecture slides are clear and the instructions for each assignment were clear. I even enjoyed the presentation aspect. I liked learning R and the assignments helped to better understand the program! It's too bad political statistical courses get a bad rap, they are fun! They allow you to be creative!

Yes, his lectures are a little hard to understand, but you will get past that, because everything is put in very simple terms.  Also, his slides are the absolute best I have ever seen, and he posts them to blackboard, even with links for further reading.  His tutorial sections are also organized so well it is impressive, with handouts prepared.

It's true he has a strong accent, so you have to listen carefully and pay attention. This is more than made up for by his excellent lecture slides. Everything is perfectly organized, well explained, so logical. Before classes started, I was sure I would have to hire a tutor, but, I expect an A and did it on my own. He makes this stuff interesting.

The lectures were very much based on the readings. Both are very crucial to success in this course.  I had a hard time understanding him sometimes throughout lecture, but he gave a lot of help when you asked for it.
HE'S GREAT but the accent ruins everything. As a student it's really bothersome to hear a fast speaker with a strong accent for 2 hours straight.
Can't hear a word he's saying
teacherRatingTags: ['Beware of pop quizzes', 'Lecture heavy', 'So many papers']

rComments: Really tough to understand when he's lecturing, God bless that he posts the slides though. Seems like a nice guy, but hard to grasp what he is saying - you will know what I mean after your first lecture.
